Judea Pearl

Biography

Pearl is an Israeli-American computer scientist and philosopher. He was born September 4, 1936, in Tel Aviv, British Mandate for Palestine (present-day Israel). In 1956, Judea decided to study engineering, after serving in the Israel Defense Forces and joining a kibbutz. In 1960 he received a Bachelor of Science degree in Electrical Engineering from Technion (Israel Institute of Technology) where he met his wife, Ruth Pearl. He then moved to the United States to pursue his graduate studies.
Pearl attended Newark College of Engineering in 1961 where he received an M.S. in Electronics. In 1965 he graduated with an M.S. in Physics from Rutgers University and a Ph.D. in electrical engineering from the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn. He started working on superconductive parametric amplifiers and storage devices at RCA Research Laboratories (now SRI International) in Princeton, New Jersey, and at Electronic Memories, Inc., on advanced memory systems. Later in 1970, he joined UCLAâ€™s School of Engineering where he started working on probabilistic artificial intelligence. Pearl is currently a professor of computer science and statistics and director of the Cognitive Systems Laboratory at UCLA.
Judea Pearl is the father of journalist Daniel Pearl, who was kidnapped and assassinated in Pakistan in 2002 by terrorists linked to Al-Qaeda and the International Islamic Front because of his American and Jewish ancestry.

Research

Judea Pearl is a pioneer of Bayesian networks and the probabilistic approach to artificial intelligence, as well as one of the first in the empirical sciences to mathematize casual modeling. His study aims to be a high-level cognitive model as well. He is passionate about science philosophy, knowledge representation, nonstandard logics, and education. UCLA computer science professor Richard Korf has referred to Pearl as "one of the giants in the field of artificial intelligence." According to the Association for Computing Machinery, his work on causation "revolutionized the concept of causality in statistics, psychology, medicine, and social sciences." He received the ACM Turing Award in 2011 for his fundamental contributions to artificial intelligence through the development of a calculus for probabilistic and causal reasoning.
